questions.text: Which of the following leads to an increase in enzyme activity?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in temperature above the optimum

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decrease in activation energy For a substrate to become a product, it goes to a transition state (S‡) which is a fleeting, momentary, unstable chemical species that is neither substrate nor product. This species has the highest free energy in a reaction coordinate diagram. This creates an energy barrier for a substrate to become a product. This energy is known as activation energy. So, activation energy is the free energy difference between substrates and that of their transition state Gibb’s Free Energy graph for enzyme- catalyzed and enzyme uncatalyzed reaction. On X-axis, reaction progress is taken (i.e. S getting converted to P). For any spontaneous reaction, S has more free energy as compared to P. For S to be converted to P, first S has to acquire activation energy and reach a high energy state (transition state). Only then it can be converted to P. The enzyme acts by decreasing the free energy of the transition state intermediate by its stabilization, so that activation energy also decreases.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Options A and C: Extremes of temperature and pH will result in enzyme denaturation and loss of activity. Option D: Enzyme activity increases with the increase in substrate concentration. So, a low substrate concentration will result in low enzyme activity.

questions.text: All of the following statements about enzymes are true EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Multienzyme complexes greatly reduce the rates of reactions

options.label: B
options.text: Isoenzymes differ in their amino acid sequence

options.label: C
options.text: Allosteric regulators do not bind to the active site of the enzyme

options.label: D
options.text: Translational regulation is the method of long-term regulation of enzymatic activity

questions.correct_answer: A. Multienzyme complexes greatly reduce the rates of reactions
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Multienzyme complexes greatly reduce the rates of reactions Multienzyme complex: Stable, non-valent assembly of different enzymes involved in consecutive reactions of a metabolic pathway e.g. PDH complex, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex. They greatly increase the rate of reactions as the product of one enzyme serves as a reactant for the next enzyme in the complex. This reduces the time for diffusion of substrates to another site in the cell, hence reaction becomes faster (so, option a is the wrong statement).

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B: Isoenzymes differ in their amino acid sequence Isoenzymes are different enzymes catalyzing the same chemical reaction. Different enzymes here mean that their amino acid sequences are different from one another (option b is correct). Option C: Allosteric regulators do not bind to the active site of the enzyme Allosteric regulators bind to a site other than the active site. This site is known as an allosteric or regulatory site (option c is correct). Regulator binding to the allosteric site causes a conformation change in the substrate which in turn help in increasing or decreasing the catalysis and rate of reaction. Option D: Translational regulation is the method of long-term regulation of enzymatic activity Translational regulation means inhibiting/activating the synthesis of enzyme/protein (protein translation) to stop/increase the reaction. It takes time and hence is a long-term regulation method (option d is also correct). On the other hand, allosteric regulation works instantaneously.

questions.text: Cytochrome Oxidase is an enzyme carrying out the transfer of electrons to the final electron acceptor O2 in ETC. The presence of which of the following is required for the proper working of this enzyme?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both A & B Cytochrome oxidase Cytochrome oxidase aka complex IV of ETC consists of a superfamily of proteins that act as the terminal enzymes of respiratory chains in a variety of organisms. It transfers electrons from cytochrome c to the final electron acceptor O 2 . Structural features of human cytochrome oxidase: It is a large multi-subunit complex with multiple heme proteins and Cu ions forming Fe-Cu centers for the transfer of electrons. Electron transfer through Complex IV is from cytochrome c to the Cu A center, to heme a, to the heme a 3 –Cu B center, and finally to O 2

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option C: Molybdenum Very small amounts of this element are present in the human body, mainly in the liver and kidneys. It is essential for the function of three enzymes: Xanthine oxidase Aldehyde oxidase Sulfite oxidase (an enzyme similar to cyt oxidase)

questions.text: Aldehyde dehydrogenase an enzyme involved in the metabolism of alcohol requires NAD+ for its proper function. Here NAD+ can be most appropriately termed as:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Coenzyme NAD + is an organic non-protein portion that is required for the enzyme, so it is a coenzyme. Examples of other coenzymes are FAD, NADP, PLP, TPP, etc.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A: Cofactor The non-protein portion of a holoenzyme is known as a cofactor. If it's organic it is called a coenzyme while an inorganic cofactor is simply known as cofactor which if bound tightly is known as the prosthetic group Option C: Apoenzyme The protein portion of the holoenzyme is known as an apoenzyme. It has an active site to bind substrate and perform catalysis with the help of a cofactor present nearby. Option D: Abenzyme Abenzyme aka abzyme is a monoclonal antibody with catalytic activity. Abzymes are produced in lab animals by immunization against synthetic haptens, but some natural abzymes can also be found in normal humans: anti-vasoactive intestinal peptide autoantibodies abzymes in patients with autoimmune diseases.

questions.text: A number of mechanisms are used by enzymes for increasing the rate of a reaction. Which of the following is NOT employed by enzymes for catalysis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increasing activation energy Enzymes increase the rate of reaction by decreasing the activation energy (Option C is false). It does so by lowering the free energy of the transition state, so that the transition state will be reached faster compared to a non-catalyzed reaction.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A: Forming non-covalent interactions Mostly in enzyme-substrate (ES) interactions, non-covalent interactions such as hydrogen, hydrophobic & ionic bonds are formed. Vander Waal forces are never seen between enzyme and substrate. These interactions will help stabilize the transition state and also help in inter or intramolecular transfer of electrons, atoms, or a functional group within or between substrate molecules. Option B: Forming acid-base interactions Enzymes can also facilitate the reaction by donating or accepting the proton from its active site acidic or basic amino acid residues. This is known as acid-base catalysis. The amino acid residue most used for this type of reaction is Histidine as it can act as both acid and base due to pKa close to 7.0. Examples of such enzymes are Chymotrypsin which uses a histidine residue as a base catalyst to increase the nucleophilic property of serine, and carbonic anhydrase which also uses histidine to remove hydrogen ions from water molecules to generate OH. Option D: Forming covalent interactions Some enzymes also perform catalysis by forming a covalent reaction intermediate with its substrate. Examples of such enzymes include PLP-dependent transaminases and TPP-dependent PDH complexes. These cofactors are generally involved in the covalent interactions and help to reduce the energy of transition states.

questions.text: Trypsin is a serine protease that cleaves proteins by the addition of water. In a polypeptide, it will act and cleave at the carboxy-terminal of which of the following amino acids?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Arginine Trypsin is a serine protease as it has a serine at its active site Trypsin cleaves a polypeptide at the carboxy-terminal of basic amino acids arginine and lysine (see fig). Amino acid triad in the active site of serine proteases consists of s erine, histidine, and aspartate. Examples of serine proteases: Chymotrypsin, Trypsin, Elastase, Thrombin, Plasmin, Complements, Factors X and XI Serine Proteases differ in substrate specificity

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A: Tryptophan Chymotrypsin-like protease have a hydrophobic binding pocket at their active site. They cleave at the carboxy-terminal of bulky hydrophobic amino acids such as tryptophan, tyrosine, and phenylalanine. Options C and D: Glycine and Alanine Elastase-like proteases have a smaller pocket at their substrate binding site compared to other proteases. So, they cleave at carboxy-terminal of small neutral amino acids e.g. Glycine, Alanine

questions.text: Arrange the enzyme categories as per increasing order of their enzyme commission numbers: A. Isomerases B. Hydrolases C. Hydratase D. Transferases Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

D→ B→C → A Name of Enzyme EC Number Transferase 2 Hydrolase 3 Hydratase 4 Isomerase 5 For details of their reaction and other categories refer to treasure attached.

questions.text: If the Serine amino acid residue present at the active site of Chymotrypsin is changed with Proline. Which of the following will happen?

options.label: A
options.text: Chymotrypsin can catalyze the protein hydrolysis but cannot bind it

options.label: B
options.text: Chymotrypsin can bind the protein but cannot catalyze its hydrolysis

options.label: C
options.text: Chymotrypsin can bind as well as can catalyze the protein hydrolysis

options.label: D
options.text: Chymotrypsin can neither bind nor can catalyze the protein hydrolysis

questions.correct_answer: B. Chymotrypsin can bind the protein but cannot catalyze its hydrolysis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chymotrypsin can bind the protein but cannot catalyze its hydrolysis Chymotrypsin is a serine protease with a catalytic triad of serine, histidine, and aspartate at its active site. During the catalysis of hydrolysis of the peptide bond, the enzyme first binds the substrate through histidine and arginine. Then the hydrolysis of the peptide bond takes place with the participation of serine residue. The question says that a site-specific/directed mutagenesis (oligonucleotide with single base change- UCA (serine) changes to CCA (proline)) is done. Histidine and Aspartate residues have the function of binding to peptide/protein substrate. As these amino acids are not changed, so, the enzyme will be able to bind ( options A and D are false ) But the hydrolysis is done by serine residue, so, the mutated enzyme in which serine is replaced with proline will not be able to catalyze the hydrolysis ( option C is false ).

questions.text: Vitamins and their derivatives constitute a majority of biological coenzymes. Which of the following is a Non-vitamin coenzyme?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lipoic acid It is an organosulfur compound formed from precursor octanoic acid (an 8C fatty acid) in the body so, it is not a vitamin. Lipoic acid acts as a coenzyme for enzymes pyruvate dehydrogenase and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase and is attached by a strong covalent bond. Another Non-vitamin coenzyme is Tetrahydrobiopterin derived from guanosine triphosphate.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A: Niacin Niacin is vitamin B 3 and works as a coenzyme in its active form Nicotinamide Adenine Dinucleotide (NAD) It is a coenzyme for a number of dehydrogenase enzymes such as PDH complex, isocitrate DH, Malate DH, etc. involved in fuel metabolism. Option B: Coenzyme A Coenzyme A is a derivative of Vitamin B5 (Pantothenic acid) It is a coenzyme for kinase or transferase enzymes that works in acyl group transfer reactions such as succinyl thiokinase, thiophorase, etc. Option D: SAM SAM (S-Adenosyl Methionine), is a methyl donor. It is neither a Coenzyme nor a Vitamin.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly defines Isoenzymes?

options.label: A
options.text: Forms of the same enzyme that catalyze the different reaction

options.label: B
options.text: Forms of the same enzyme that catalyze the same reaction

options.label: C
options.text: Forms of the different enzymes that catalyze the different reaction

options.label: D
options.text: Forms of the different enzymes that catalyze the same reaction

questions.correct_answer: B. Forms of the same enzyme that catalyze the same reaction
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Forms of the same enzyme that catalyze the same reaction Isozymes/Isoenzymes are different forms of the same enzyme , catalyzing the same reaction in the same species (Options A and C are false) For e xample, there are five isozymes of Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH-1 to LDH-5), All convert Pyruvate to Lactate. So, for isoenzymes, the reaction and species will always be the same.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option D: Forms of the different enzymes that catalyze the same reaction If two enzymes are from two different species, they are different enzymes but they can still catalyze the same reaction in their respective species. The term used for such enzymes is Alloenzyme and not isoenzymes For example, DNA polymerase from different species have the different structure the but same function of DNA polymerization by phosphodiester bonds. Isoenzymes may be present in the same/different tissues but never in two different species.

questions.text: Isoenzymes can be differentiated from each other by
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Identification of Isoenzymes: In polyacrylamide gel or agar gel electrophoresis, the isoenzymes have different mobility due to the difference in their MW. LDH, CK, and ALP isoenzymes can be separated by electrophoresis (Option A is true) . Heat stability: One of the isoenzymes may be easily denatured by heat, e.g. bone isoenzyme of ALP (BALP) while other liver ALP is much more heat stable (Option B is true) Inhibitors: One of the isoenzymes may be sensitive to one inhibitor, e.g. tartrate labile ACP (ACP-1, 2, 3 and 6) vs Tartrate resistant ACP (TRAP) ACP-5 K m value or substrate specificity may be different for isoenzymes, e.g. glucokinase has high K m and hexokinase has low K m for glucose. Glucokinase specifically acts on glucose as a substrate while hexokinase can phosphorylate any hexose sugar (Option C is true) . Co-factor requirements can be different for isoenzymes, for example, the cytoplasmic isoenzyme of isocitrate dehydrogenase is NADP + dependent whereas Mitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase is NAD + dependent. Tissue localization may be different for isoenzymes. The H4 form of LDH is present in the heart, while the M4 variety is present in skeletal muscle. Specific antibodies may identify different types of isoenzymes. For example, CK isoenzymes are separated by different antibodies.

questions.text: Argininosuccinate synthetase (EC 6.3.4.5) links aspartate and citrulline via the amino group of aspartate and provides the second nitrogen of urea. The reaction requires ATP and involves the intermediate formation of citrullyl-AMP. Subsequent displacement of AMP by aspartate then forms argininosuccinate. Select the class of enzyme that the enzyme belongs?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ligases Argininosuccinate synthetase (EC 6.3.4.5) belongs to ligases. Argininosuccinate synthase or synthetase is an enzyme that catalyzes the synthesis of argininosuccinate from citrulline and aspartate.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A. Transferases Transferases are enzymes transferring a group, e.g. a methyl group or a glycosyl group, from one compound (generally regarded as a donor) to another compound (generally regarded as an acceptor). Option C. Lyases Lyases are enzymes cleaving C-C, C-O, C-N, and other bonds by elimination, leaving double bonds or rings, or conversely adding groups to double bonds. Option D. Hydrolases These enzymes catalyze the hydrolytic cleavage of C-O, C-N, C-C, and some other bonds, including phosphoric anhydride bonds

questions.text: Glucokinase is an enzyme that facilitates the phosphorylation of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. It plays an important role in the regulation of carbohydrate metabolism by acting as a glucose sensor, triggering shifts in metabolism or cell function in response to rising or falling levels of glucose. Select the appropriate class of enzyme to which glucokinase belong?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Transferase Glucokinase (GK) is a hexokinase isozyme, related homologously to at least three other hexokinases. All of the hexokinases can mediate the phosphorylation of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate (G6P), which is the first step of both glycogen synthesis and glycolysis.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option Transferase enzymes that catalyze the transfer of moieties such as glycosyl, methyl, or phosphoryl groups Option Hydrolase enzymes that catalyze hydrolytic cleavage of C—C, C— O, C—N, and other covalent bonds. Option C. Reductase Enzymes that catalyze the addition of hydrogen or removal of oxygen from the substrate.
